title: What’s Wrong with OOP and FP

cells.data:

</xml><![endif]--><!--[if gte mso 9]><xml>

	{mso-style-name:普通表格;

<!--StartFragment-->

<p class="MsoNormal" align="left"><span lang="EN-US" style="font-size:16.0pt;font-family:"Helvetica Neue",sans-serif;mso-bidi-font-family:
"Helvetica Neue";color:#262626;mso-font-kerning:0pt">I don’t understand why
there are endless debates about Object-Oriented Programming (OOP) and
Functional Programming (FP). It seems that this type of thing is at the limits
of human intelligence, so you can argue about them for centuries. Over the
years of doing programming languages research, I have seen the answer clearly,
so I often find it pointless debating with people on these issues.<o:p></o:p></span></p>

<p class="MsoNormal" align="left"><span lang="EN-US" style="font-size:16.0pt;font-family:"Helvetica Neue",sans-serif;mso-bidi-font-family:
"Helvetica Neue";color:#262626;mso-font-kerning:0pt">In short, both OOP and FP
are wrong when you go to the extreme. The extreme of OOP is the notion <i>everything
is an object (pure OO)</i> . The extreme of FP is a <i>purely functional
language</i> .<o:p></o:p></span></p>

<p class="MsoNormal" align="left"><b><span lang="EN-US" style="font-size:18.0pt;font-family:"Helvetica Neue",sans-serif;mso-bidi-font-family:
"Helvetica Neue";color:#262626;mso-font-kerning:0pt">What’s wrong with OOP<o:p></o:p></span></b></p>

<p class="MsoNormal" align="left"><span lang="EN-US" style="font-size:16.0pt;font-family:"Helvetica Neue",sans-serif;mso-bidi-font-family:
"Helvetica Neue";color:#262626;mso-font-kerning:0pt">OOP is wrong because of
its definition of an “object”, and its attempt of trying to fit everything into
it. When that goes to the extreme, you arrive at the notion “e <i>verything is
an object</i> “. But this notion is wrong, because<o:p></o:p></span></p>

<p class="MsoNormal" align="left"><i><span lang="EN-US" style="font-size:16.0pt;font-family:"Helvetica Neue",sans-serif;mso-bidi-font-family:
"Helvetica Neue";color:#262626;mso-font-kerning:0pt">There exists things that
are not objects. Functions are not objects.<o:p></o:p></span></i></p>

<p class="MsoNormal" align="left"><span lang="EN-US" style="font-size:16.0pt;font-family:"Helvetica Neue",sans-serif;mso-bidi-font-family:
"Helvetica Neue";color:#262626;mso-font-kerning:0pt">You may argue that in
Python or Scala, functions are also objects. In Python, every object with the
method <i>__call__</i> is a function. Likewise, in Scala, functions are just
objects with a method named <i>apply</i> .  But after some careful
thought, you will see that this is confusing the fundamental with the
derived. Functions are fundamental, but objects containing them are
derived. __call__ and apply are <i>themselves</i> the “function objects”
you are trying to define in the first place. Python and Scala
just kidnapped the functions, jailed them into “objects”, labeled them
“__call__” and “apply”, and then call them “methods”. Of course, when you wrap
a function into an object, you can use the object like a function, but this
doesn’t mean you can say “functions are also objects”.<o:p></o:p></span></p>

<p class="MsoNormal" align="left"><span lang="EN-US" style="font-size:16.0pt;font-family:"Helvetica Neue",sans-serif;mso-bidi-font-family:
"Helvetica Neue";color:#262626;mso-font-kerning:0pt">Most OO languages also
lack correct implementations of first-class functions. An extreme is Java,
which doesn’t allow functions to be passed as data at all. You can always wrap
functions into objects and call them “methods”, but as I said, that’s
kidnapping. The lack of first-class functions is the major reason why there are
so many “design patterns” in Java. Once you have first-class functions, you
will need almost none of the design patterns.<o:p></o:p></span></p>

<p class="MsoNormal" align="left"><b><span lang="EN-US" style="font-size:18.0pt;font-family:"Helvetica Neue",sans-serif;mso-bidi-font-family:
"Helvetica Neue";color:#262626;mso-font-kerning:0pt">What’s wrong with FP<o:p></o:p></span></b></p>

<p class="MsoNormal" align="left"><span lang="EN-US" style="font-size:16.0pt;font-family:"Helvetica Neue",sans-serif;mso-bidi-font-family:
"Helvetica Neue";color:#262626;mso-font-kerning:0pt">Similarly, FP is
wrong when you get to its extreme, a <i>purely functional language</i> . To
discuss the topic, it is better to first have a good understanding what is a
purely functional language. For this, you may want to read  <a href="http://www.cs.indiana.edu/~sabry/papers/purelyFunctional.ps"><b><i><span style="color:#828282;text-decoration:none;text-underline:none">What is a Purely
Functional Language</span></i></b></a>  by Amr Sabry (who was my PhD
advisor). But in short, a purely functional language is wrong because<o:p></o:p></span></p>

<p class="MsoNormal" align="left"><i><span lang="EN-US" style="font-size:16.0pt;font-family:"Helvetica Neue",sans-serif;mso-bidi-font-family:
"Helvetica Neue";color:#262626;mso-font-kerning:0pt">There exists things that
are not pure. Side-effects are very real.<o:p></o:p></span></i></p>

<p class="MsoNormal" align="left"><span lang="EN-US" style="font-size:16.0pt;font-family:"Helvetica Neue",sans-serif;mso-bidi-font-family:
"Helvetica Neue";color:#262626;mso-font-kerning:0pt">Being purely functional is
basically ignoring the capabilities provided by the physical substrate (silicon
chips, quantum chips or whatever). Instead, purely functional languages try to
reimplement the universe in functions by passing the universe in and out. But
there is a difference between the <i>physical</i> and the <i>simulated</i> .
“side-effects” are physical. They truly exist in nature and are indispensable
for computation to be efficient. Simulating them with pure functions is
doomed to be inefficient, complicated and even ugly. Have you noticed how easy
it is to implement circular data structures or random number generators in C?
The same is not true for Haskell.<o:p></o:p></span></p>

<p class="MsoNormal" align="left"><span lang="EN-US" style="font-size:16.0pt;font-family:"Helvetica Neue",sans-serif;mso-bidi-font-family:
"Helvetica Neue";color:#262626;mso-font-kerning:0pt">Also purely functional
languages cause a huge cognitive cost. If you look deep into them, monads
make programs complicated and hard to write, and monad transformers are just
ugly hacks. They are in the same spirit of “Java design patterns”. Have you
noticed how many easy things in other languages become research problems when
you try to write them in Haskell? So you often see papers titled like “A
Monadic Approach to a-solved-problem”. Interestingly, Amr Sabry coauthored such
a </span><span lang="EN-US"><a href="http://okmij.org/ftp/papers/LogicT.pdf"><b><i><span style="font-size:16.0pt;font-family:"Helvetica Neue",sans-serif;mso-bidi-font-family:
"Helvetica Neue";color:#828282;mso-font-kerning:0pt;text-decoration:none;
text-underline:none">paper</span></i></b></a></span><span lang="EN-US" style="font-size:16.0pt;font-family:"Helvetica Neue",sans-serif;mso-bidi-font-family:
"Helvetica Neue";color:#262626;mso-font-kerning:0pt"> . The story was, he tried
to reimplement Dan Friedman’s </span><span lang="EN-US"><a href="http://minikanren.org/"><b><i><span style="font-size:16.0pt;font-family:
"Helvetica Neue",sans-serif;mso-bidi-font-family:"Helvetica Neue";color:#828282;
mso-font-kerning:0pt;text-decoration:none;text-underline:none">miniKanren</span></i></b></a></span><span lang="EN-US" style="font-size:16.0pt;font-family:"Helvetica Neue",sans-serif;
mso-bidi-font-family:"Helvetica Neue";color:#262626;mso-font-kerning:0pt"> in
Haskell, but couldn’t figure out how to compose the monads. He had to seek help
from Oleg Kiselyov, arguably the world’s most knowledgeable person about
Haskell’s type system. And if you don’t know, Amr Sabry is probably the world’s
most knowledgeable person about purely functional programming languages. They
coauthored a paper after solving the problem with Oleg’s help. Ironically, Dan
Friedman, the original author of that piece of code, didn’t have any such
trouble writing it in Scheme.<o:p></o:p></span></p>

<p class="MsoNormal" align="left"><span lang="EN-US" style="font-size:16.0pt;font-family:"Helvetica Neue",sans-serif;mso-bidi-font-family:
"Helvetica Neue";color:#262626;mso-font-kerning:0pt">Some people claim that the
value of monads is that they “delimit” the side-effects. But what’s the use of the
delimiting if monads don’t really make your program easier to analyze or safer?
In fact, they don’t. It is just as hard to analyze as if you use
side-effects. There is no such thing monads can make easier which can’t be
done by static analysis. Every static analysis researcher knows this. Static
analyses use what is essentially monads, and they take the burden of writing
monadic code away from programmers, instead of imposing it on them. Of course
overusing side-effects will make programs harder to analyze, but you can also
write pure functions in C, for example:<o:p></o:p></span></p>

<p class="MsoNormal" align="left"><b><span lang="EN-US" style="font-size:14.0pt;font-family:"Menlo Bold",sans-serif;color:#262626;
mso-font-kerning:0pt">int f(int x) {<o:p></o:p></span></b></p>

<p class="MsoNormal" align="left"><b><span lang="EN-US" style="font-size:14.0pt;font-family:"Menlo Bold",sans-serif;color:#262626;
mso-font-kerning:0pt">    int y = </span></b><b><span lang="EN-US" style="font-size:14.0pt;font-family:"Menlo Bold",sans-serif;
color:#730002;mso-font-kerning:0pt">0</span></b><b><span lang="EN-US" style="font-size:14.0pt;font-family:"Menlo Bold",sans-serif;color:#262626;
mso-font-kerning:0pt">;<o:p></o:p></span></b></p>

<p class="MsoNormal" align="left"><b><span lang="EN-US" style="font-size:14.0pt;font-family:"Menlo Bold",sans-serif;color:#262626;
mso-font-kerning:0pt">    int z = </span></b><b><span lang="EN-US" style="font-size:14.0pt;font-family:"Menlo Bold",sans-serif;
color:#730002;mso-font-kerning:0pt">0</span></b><b><span lang="EN-US" style="font-size:14.0pt;font-family:"Menlo Bold",sans-serif;color:#262626;
mso-font-kerning:0pt">;<o:p></o:p></span></b></p>

<p class="MsoNormal" align="left"><b><span lang="EN-US" style="font-size:14.0pt;font-family:"Menlo Bold",sans-serif;color:#262626;
mso-font-kerning:0pt">    y = </span></b><b><span lang="EN-US" style="font-size:14.0pt;font-family:"Menlo Bold",sans-serif;
color:#730002;mso-font-kerning:0pt">2</span></b><b><span lang="EN-US" style="font-size:14.0pt;font-family:"Menlo Bold",sans-serif;color:#262626;
mso-font-kerning:0pt"> * x;<o:p></o:p></span></b></p>

<p class="MsoNormal" align="left"><b><span lang="EN-US" style="font-size:14.0pt;font-family:"Menlo Bold",sans-serif;color:#262626;
mso-font-kerning:0pt">    z = y + </span></b><b><span lang="EN-US" style="font-size:14.0pt;font-family:"Menlo Bold",sans-serif;
color:#730002;mso-font-kerning:0pt">1</span></b><b><span lang="EN-US" style="font-size:14.0pt;font-family:"Menlo Bold",sans-serif;color:#262626;
mso-font-kerning:0pt">;<o:p></o:p></span></b></p>

<p class="MsoNormal" align="left"><b><span lang="EN-US" style="font-size:14.0pt;font-family:"Menlo Bold",sans-serif;color:#262626;
mso-font-kerning:0pt">    return z / </span></b><b><span lang="EN-US" style="font-size:14.0pt;font-family:"Menlo Bold",sans-serif;
color:#730002;mso-font-kerning:0pt">3</span></b><b><span lang="EN-US" style="font-size:14.0pt;font-family:"Menlo Bold",sans-serif;color:#262626;
mso-font-kerning:0pt">;<o:p></o:p></span></b></p>

<p class="MsoNormal" align="left"><b><span lang="EN-US" style="font-size:14.0pt;font-family:"Menlo Bold",sans-serif;color:#262626;
mso-font-kerning:0pt">}  </span></b><span lang="EN-US" style="font-size:14.0pt;font-family:"Menlo Regular",sans-serif;
color:#343434;mso-font-kerning:0pt"><o:p></o:p></span></p>

<p class="MsoNormal" align="left"><span lang="EN-US" style="font-size:16.0pt;font-family:"Helvetica Neue",sans-serif;mso-bidi-font-family:
"Helvetica Neue";color:#262626;mso-font-kerning:0pt">You can do the same with
assembly language too. Pure functions don’t just belong to purely functional
languages. You can write pure functions in any language, but the important
thing is, you should be allowed to use side-effects too.<o:p></o:p></span></p>

<p class="MsoNormal" align="left"><span lang="EN-US" style="font-size:16.0pt;font-family:"Helvetica Neue",sans-serif;mso-bidi-font-family:
"Helvetica Neue";color:#262626;mso-font-kerning:0pt">Looking back into history,
the idealism from mathematics is the driving force behind purely functional
languages. Mathematical functions are simple and beautiful, but
unfortunately they work well only when the thing you are trying to model is
pure by nature. Otherwise it becomes ugly. Don’t be frightened by buzzwords
like “category theory”. I know a considerable amount of category theory. Even
the category theorists themselves call it “abstract nonsense”, because it is
basically a grotesque way of saying what you already know! If you read
Gottlob Frege’s article  <a href="http://www.olimon.org/uan/frege-writings.pdf"><b><i><span style="color:#828282;text-decoration:none;text-underline:none">Function and
concept</span></i></b></a><i> , </i>you will be surprised that most
mathematicians got functions wrong before his writing, and that was just a
little more than a hundred years ago. In fact, mathematics have done so many
things wrong with its language, especially in things like calculus. There is no
reason programming language designers should blindly learn from mathematics.<o:p></o:p></span></p>

<p class="MsoNormal" align="left"><b><span lang="EN-US" style="font-size:18.0pt;font-family:"Helvetica Neue",sans-serif;mso-bidi-font-family:
"Helvetica Neue";color:#262626;mso-font-kerning:0pt">Don’t fall in love with
you model<o:p></o:p></span></b></p>

<p class="MsoNormal" align="left"><span lang="EN-US" style="font-size:16.0pt;font-family:"Helvetica Neue",sans-serif;mso-bidi-font-family:
"Helvetica Neue";color:#262626;mso-font-kerning:0pt">Everything starts to do
harm when they are pursued to the extreme. When going to the extremes, both OOP
and FP try to fit the world into their peculiar models, but the world works in
a way completely independent of what we think. It is wrong to think of
everything as a nail when you have a hammer. Only by observing the reality can
we get out of the religions that are limiting us.<o:p></o:p></span></p>

<p class="MsoNormal"><i><span lang="EN-US" style="font-size:16.0pt;font-family:
"Helvetica Neue",sans-serif;mso-bidi-font-family:"Helvetica Neue";color:#262626;
mso-font-kerning:0pt">Don’t fit the world to your model. Fit your model to the
world.</span></i><span lang="EN-US"><o:p></o:p></span></p>

<!--EndFragment-->
